awd_titl_txt: Conference: Joint Alabama--Florida Conference on Differential Equations, Dynamical Systems and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The conference "Joint Alabama-Florida Conference on Differential Equations, Dynamical Systems and Applications  (JAF DE-DS)" organized by the departments of Mathematics and Statistics at Auburn University, the University of Alabama at Birmingham, Florida International University, and Florida State University will take place in Auburn, AL, May 13-14, 2023. This conference will bring together a diverse group of researchers in the geographic area near the states of Alabama and Florida. The award funds will help defray travel and local expenses of the participants with no current federal support, graduate and undergraduate students, postdoctoral fellows, early career researchers, and scientists from under-represented groups in STEM. 

Thematically, the conference will be centered around a broad set of topics in partial differential equations including dynamics of nonlinear waves in dispersive and dissipative systems, long-term behavior of evolution equations, reaction-diffusion equations, pattern formation, and applied spectral theory. The main research directions are reaction-diffusion equations (population dynamics, chemotaxis, and combustion models), models of fluid and gas dynamics, novel mechanisms in stability analysis of nonlinear waves (Maslov index). More information can be found on the conference website: 
https://www.auburn.edu/cosam/al_fl_differential_conference/index.htm

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project provided support for students, postdoctoral fellows, early career researchers, and more senior mathematicians to participate in the first "Joint Alabama-Florida Conference on Differential Equations, Dynamical Systems and Applications (JAF DEDS)" held at Auburn University, May 13-14, 2023. The main topics of the conference were centered around existence, dynamics, and long-term behavior of waves in the models of mathematical biology (Fisher-KPP equation), physics (Schrodinger equation), as well as ecology and sociology (Keller-Segel system). The research outcomes of this conference provided new insights into highly relevant phenomena such as propagation of flame fronts in wildfires, ormation of water waves near shallow coastal regions, localization of waves in quantum systems. 

This conference was attended by 60 participants. It featured 3 pleanary talks, 9 invited talks, and a poster session. 

Plenary speakers: 

  • Vera Hur, Professor, Department Chair,  Philippe Tondeur Scholar in the Department of Mathematics and a Brad and Karen Smith Professorial Scholar of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Talk: “Stable undular bores: rigorous analysis and validated numerics”
  • Andrej Zlatos, Professor, Department  of Mathematics, University of California, San Diego. Talk: “Homogenization in front propagation models”
  • Kevin Zumbrun, Distinguished Professor, Department of  Mathematics, Indiana University, Bloomington. Talk: “Singular amplitude equations and Eckhaus type stability criteria for convective Turing bifurcation with conservation laws”

Invited speakers:

  • Peter Howard (Professor, Texas A&M University)
  • Yuri Latushkin (Emeritus Professor, University of Missouri, Columbia)
  • Maria Amarakristi Onyido (Assistant Professor, Northern Illinois University)
  • Matthew Powell (Postdoctoral Fellow, Georgia Institute of Technology)
  • Rachidi Salako (Assistant Professor, University of Nevada, Las Vegas)
  • Maja Taskovic (Assistant Professor, Emory University)
  • Rudi Weikard (Professor, University of Alabama at Birmingham)
  • Shuwen Xue (Assistant Professor, Northern Illinois University)
  • Angel Zhivkov (Professor Sofia University, Bulgaria)

Early career researchers, students, and postdoctoral fellows were provided ample opportunities to communicate with and receive feedback from the internationally recognized leaders in partial differential equations and dynamical systems. This critically important interaction was facilitated by the conference poster session, invited talks by early career mathematicians, and plenary talks by the leading experts in fields of differential equations and dynamical systems.

 


Last Modified: 07/10/2024
Modified by: Selim Sukhtaiev
